text:
Instead of one large quiche, I pour the mixture into the bottoms of a greased muffin pan, a little less than half full.  It makes bite sized portions that are perfect for a party.  My friends always ask me for "my recipe"!  Easy and delicious.  Oh, I use whatever shredded cheese is on sale at the store.

country:
None
text:
I HAVE BEEN MAKING THIS ( VERY SIMILIAR ) FOR YEARS . I USE A 10 OZ. PACKAGE FROZEN SPIANCH (DEFROSTED ), 4 EGGS , 2 1/2 CUPS MIXTURE OF ANY TYPE OF CHEESES ( I LIKE SWISS WITH PARMESAN OR MOZZAELLA WITH RICOTTA ) , ANYTHING WORKS . I THROW IN CHOPPED SCALLIONS , A TOUCH OF NUTMEG AND GARLIC SALT . I ALSO TOP WITH BOTTLED MUSHROOM SLICES , GREEN OLIVES , TOMATO SLICES  OR WHATEVER I HAVE ON HAND . BAKE AT 375 ,IN A 9 " PIE PAN , FOR 30 MINUTES , OR UNTIL THE EDGE STARS TO BROWN AND THE CENTER NO LONGER BUBBLES ( WITH MOISTURE ) . WHEN ENTERTAINING , I DOUBLE THE RECIPE AND BAKE IN A 9" X 13" GLASS BAKING DISH , CUT INTO SMALL SQUARES AND SERVED AT ROOM TEMPERATURE. IT IS ALWAYS IS A HIT .

text:
Yummy!  I didn't use muenster cheese.  Instead, to make this lower fat, I used 3 eggs, 1/2 cup light sharp cheddar, 1 cup fat free cottage cheese, and a 1/4 cup light parmesan cheese.  I added a few sliced mushrooms and green onion in the saute.  Although not as rich, still tasty and forgiving recipe.

text:
My husband lost nearly 30 pounds on the Atkins diet, and this is his favorite breakfast! I bake a quiche each Sunday night, and he just heats up a slice before work. 
I substitute sharp cheddar for the muenster, but cut the amount to two cups. I also add about four ounces of lean chopped ham, along with a little minced garlic. Delicious!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love the base of this recipe but when made as is, it was too thin and stiff from too much spinach. I made it as written the first time and ended up with a very stiff, thin, dry spinach pie. I have continued to use this recipe so to speak, but have since used 5 large eggs, only about 1/2 to 2/3 of the spinach called for, chopped bell peppers and 1/4 cup milk, and only 2 cups of cheese (I usually use cheddar). Other add-ins I have used with fantastic results - 1/2 cup cottage cheese in place of cheese, 1/2 cooked chopped bacon or ham, 1 can diced green chilies, chopped sun dried tomatoes, 1/4 cup crumbled blue cheese  or feta, mushrooms (saute first), or caramelized onions.  I usually assemble this the night before and just pop it in the oven the next morning. With extra eggs and milk, I add about 4-5 min. of cooking time. Also, no need to saute spinach. I just drain and squeeze it dry before throwing into the egg mixture. If using onions, sauteeing is a must.  With more eggs and some milk, you get a slightly thicker, more moist and tender quiche.  You will never miss the crust it's so good.

text:
I've adapted this recipe to be a bit healthier - I use EggBeaters in place of the eggs, use lowfat feta cheese and I put in a bit of chopped lean ham.  I bake them in muffin tins and two muffin sized mini quiches are less than 100 calories (2 points if you're a Weight Watcher!).  I slightly under cook them so I can pop them in the microwave at work for a nice breakfast.

text:
Very gourmet yet simple to make. Substituting 1 c. chopped scallions for the diced onion cuts down the frying time and gives a nice aroma - just add directly to the egg mixture. Freshly chopped herbs can also be added such as dill or basil for a fragrant aroma. If using fresh spinach instead of frozen, use 8 c. washed and chopped. Excellent!

text:
I made these in regular muffin tins it was enough to make about 14 muffin size quiches.  There were done at about 25 minutes.  I made a few in mini muffin tins just to test it and these turned out great too and were done in about 20 minutes.  (My oven usually takes a few extra minutes to cook things).  I brought these to a brunch with 6 people and they were gone in about 3 minutes, before we even sat down to eat.

Update: I made again recently and substituted 1 cup of cheese with one cup of cottage cheese.  It worked great and you would have never known there was cottage cheese in them.  Since cottage cheese is denser I got a few extra "muffins" (18 exactly)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this as a base recipe. You can add pretty much whatever you like to the base to make it your own. My first cooking included chopped green chiles and jalepeno peppers. I then sliced cherry tomatoes to garnish on top before going in the oven, and served with sour cream and salsa. It was beautiful and was a HUGE success. Everyone had seconds.  My second cooking had a Greek flair. I used Feta cheese, added chopped artichoke hearts, oregano, six large shrimp arranged on top as a garnish, etc. I say "etc." because you really can custom this to ANY taste you desire. Only hard fast rules are to use 6 eggs instead of the suggested 5, and depending on the ingredients you opt in, you will have to adjust the cooking time up -- check in 3-5 minute intervals until a knife comes out clean. Have fun! Experiment. It's all good!

text:
This is probably one of my favorite foods. I could eat it every day and not get tired of it! The only changes I make are using fresh spinach (melt the butter in the skillet, cook the onions in the butter, add 10 ounces fresh spinach until wilted; let cool slightly and chop with a knife on a cutting board) and using whatever cheese I have on hand (usually cheddar; I've actually never tried it with Muenster cheese). I've also mixed in fresh, firm, diced tomatoes and it's good. This is a spring/summer standby in our house; even two out of my three kids love it.

text:
I would give this recipe a 4.5, but a 5 with these changes - I cut the spinach down by almost a half. All of the spinach was too much and made it too dense. I also added two finely crushed fresh garlic cloves, added about 1/2 cup of shredded parmesan, and about two tablespoons of finely diced red peppers. I also used the mini muffin pan since this was for a brunch party. I first filled them 3/4 of the way and they turned out too dry so the next time I filled them to the top and they puffed up perfectly and they were so moist and fluffy. It took about 25 minutes at 350 degrees. They were such a hit and they popped out just perfectly!! Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I made this tonight for dinner, but I made it in the nonstick skillet that I sauteed the veggies in(mushrooms,onions, spinach).  I simply put the egg mixture in and covered it, cooking it on low, and lightly tossing it to have it cook through.  It formed beautifully and I put shredded sharp cheddar on the top with diced tomatoes and crumbled bacon.  Turned the heat off and let it set for a few minutes - it cut just like a pizza/pie.  My husband raved over it.  All in all it took me less than 1/2 hour from beginning to plate!

My tip for this delicious recipe? Sprinkle 1/4 cup of shredded parmesan cheese on top of the quiche before it goes in the oven. This will add a slightly browned, crispy crust on top that adds a little texture, and makes for a beautiful presentation!

city:

country:
None
text:
I love this recipe. You can do anything to it and it is very forgiving and tasty! The first time I made this I wanted it a little less dense, so I cut the spinach in half and added fresh mushrooms,it was delicious! Since then I have used sauteed asparagus tips, smoked salmon and brie (that's my favorite) chopped apple wood smoked bacon etc... and I only use 1 cup of shredded cheese and 2 oz low fat feta  or 3 sticks of lowfat string cheese(chopped) and 2 tablespoons of freshly grated parmesan cheese. I also only use 2 eggs and 1 cup of egg whites it is always delicious and healthy! Each slice is about 160 to 200 calories! If you do use egg whites you have to increase the cooking time to 45 minutes, and cover with tin foil for the first 35 min., though, well worth the wait! I make this recipe different every week and eat a slice for breakfast on my way out the door. Yummy!

text:
I have been using this recipe for several months now, and it is awesome!  I use fresh spinach that I rinse and microwave for about a minute before adding it to the onions, and I use less spinach than is called for.  I recently found myself with only Mexican style cheese on hand, so I stirred in some salsa with the spinach and onion and it was incredible!!  What I really like about this recipe is that you can pretty much throw in anything you have on hand (bacon & sausage are favorites at my house) and use any kind of cheese, and it still turns out great.

text:
Yummy! I had every intention of making this to recipe but got carried away. My changes were sauteeing the onion in 1 lb of sausage, adding that to 8 eggs beaten, 3/4 cup of milk, dry ground mustard, garlic powder, 2 oz. pimientos, used italian blend cheeses. Mixed wll, poured into a 9x13 that I had sprayed with baking spray. Baked for 40 minutes and let sit for 10. Perfect! Nice Sunday morning dish!

text:
I have made this for a few different breakfast events and it is very popular. For the most part I double the recipe because I am making it for large groups. Next time I will try the muffin tin idea. I do add one more egg but otherwise have made the recipe as written. A recommendation from the deli dept. for Muenster cheese was to use either Boars Head brand or Finlandia. Both of these are not too soft and will shred easily. I have added sliced tomatoes on top and that adds to the presentation. I also like the idea of roasted red peppers mixed in. There are so many options!

text:
this was very delicious, however i did change a few things.  I used fresh spinach, green onions, dill and parsley and cooked them together for a few minutes on the stove.  I only used ~ 1 cup of cheese (i've used more before and thought it was a bit too greasy) and added 2 extra eggs.  I sliced some tomatoes on top and crumbled feta.  one of the best quiches i've ever made!

text:
This is SO super easy and SO delicious.  I use whatever shredded cheese I happen to have in the house.  So far I've tried it with shredded 4 Cheese Mexican (so-so), shredded muenster (very good, but more work because I had to shred the cheese myself) and tonight I used shredded sharp cheddar (best yet).  I also used LOTS of mushrooms (about 2 cups) and 1 cup of onions.  I love making this in a muffin tin.  Not only do the mini-quiches look darling, but they all have a yummy crust going around the entire little quiche.  I will be experimenting with Egg Beaters and low fat cheese to make this a tad healthier.  Bon appetit!

Actually, more like four and a half stars.  I think it could be five though, with some changes.  I added tarragon and nutmeg, because the recipe didn't seem to call for enough spice.  I think next time, I will add even more tarragon and nutmeg.  My boyfriend suggested less spinach, and maybe add some other veggie.  Perhaps mushrooms, or red peppers?  Also, Muenster cheese is pretty mellow, might go with something sharper.  I used shallots instead of regular onion and sauteed it with about a clove of garlic.  I might step it up on the garlic next time too.

None
text:
This was my first time making and eating a crustless quiche so I wasn't sure what to expect. I wanted a healthy breakfast and we love quiche so I decided to give this a try… and make it even a little healthier. It was delicious! It's easy to warm up a slice for a quick breakfast. With the following modifications there are 240 calories per slice: I added chopped mushrooms with the spinach and sautéed together with the onions, decreased the cheese to 2 cups using an 8 oz block of swiss that I shredded, added 1/2 cup of low fat cottage cheese, added a few green onions and topped with roma tomato slices. I read online that your quiche is done when the internal temperature reaches 170 degrees. Do not let it go over 185 degrees as it will get tough.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
An absolutely wonderful recipe!!!  Very forgiving also.  I used a 14 oz. pkg. of frozen spinach. I sauteed some fresh mushroom(could use canned if that is all you have) in with the onion and several cloves of garlic.  This is the second time I have done this and this time added fresh chard from the garden, about 8 stalks, cook the stalks with the onion and garlic, then the chopped tops with the spinach.  Also added fresh parsley.  I added some low fat cottage cheeese and about 2 C. of mixed cheeses (all I had), a mix of cheddar and mozarella, though any cheese will do. (used jack/cheddar last time)  I also added plenty of ground pepper and some salt, generous grinding of fresh nutmeg (note to newer cooks, buy a nutmeg grinder or a rasp, and nutmegs, then are they are always fresh)and fresh basil(dried in a pinch). I used the 6 eggs and a splash of milk this time as I had more veggies but the number can be changed depending on how much veggie you use.  And, to make it even easier, use a pan that will go into the oven - cook everything, add the eggs/cheese and cook in the pan.  A one dish meal!!  Just wonderful and delicious!!

city:

text:
Fractured my foot, in pain, can't walk, alone at home...WHAT DO I EAT???   Hobbled over to the kitchen....well...considering I had to use what was in my fridge I made quite a considerable amount of changes to this recipe.   I'm not so sure about the combination of ingredients I have in my fridge! LOL  While kneeling on a kitchen chair in front of the stove to keep pressure off my foot, I greased a 9" square baking pan with olive oil and lined the bottom and sides with 2 sliced boiled potatoes. Sprinkled potato with 1/4 tsp: salt, pepper, oregano, paprika, and garlic powder. Sprinkled a little more olive oil over seasoned potato. Placed in oven at 350 and baked until slightly browned (about 20 minutes).   Meanwhile, I diced 3 small red onions & 4 garlic cloves and sauteed in 1 tablespoon olive oil until softened. Then I stirred in 1 cup sliced cremini mushrooms and corn removed from 2 corn on the cobs. Sauteed until tender. Removed from heat, stirred in a handful chopped cilantro.  In a large bowl I beat 6 eggs. Beat in 1/2 cup milk, 1/2 tsp paprika & cumino, 1/4 teaspoon: salt, pepper, & crushed oregano. Stirred into 2 cups mozzarella cheese into eggs. Stirred vegetable mixture into eggs. Poured over potatoes. Smoothed out with back of spoon. Topped with slices of tomato. Placed in oven uncovered (wanted liquid from tomato & corn to evaporate).  Meanwhile,pureed: 1 avocado, 1 jalapeno, 4 tomatillos, 1/2 lime juiced, pinch salt, pinch ground cumino, 1 small red onion, 2 garlic

Nummy! This is *fantastic*! I used a stalk of fresh spinach rather than the 10 oz frozen package- after you cut the stems off and chop it up the fresh spinach ends up being about the same amount when you saute it in the oil. I used olive oil and added quite a few extra seasonings, and although the olive oil was great I overseasoned it. I thought that with that much spinach it would need to be seasoned a lot more than the recipe stated but I was wrong! Maybe a little sprinkling of herbs on top next time and it'll be perfect.

text:
This is a delicious and healthy recipe.  I took other's suggestion to personalize my quiche.  I use fresh baby spinach, mushrooms, shredded carrot, diced red pepper, 6 eggs, a good pinch of cayenne pepper, salt and pepper.  I also like cheddar cheese and only use 2 cups.  It is a very versitle recipe. I then top it with slices of tomatoe.  I'm sure I will experiment with other vegetables.  The leftovers are very good. I like to make up a quiche let it cool and then cut up and store for breakfast and lunches.  My husband loves taking it to work with him for breakfast.

text:
Great recipe. This was made on a rainy day and I did not want to go outside. I used ingredients that were in my kitchen already. I used frozen broccoli instead of spinach.  After microwaving the broccoli for a few minutes, I cut it into small pieces. I used butter instead of vegetable oil. Instead of the cheese the recipe called for, I used 1 cup of Colby and Monterey Jack blend and 1 cup of Parmesan. I did not have a single onion in my kitchen so I used 2 cloves of garlic (chopped), Emeril's Original Essence, and a few dashes of salt. Also, I lightly sprayed my glass baking dish with cooking spray before putting the mixture in.

text:
This is a winner tonight! Husband asked for it to be placed on the main list of dinners to have and he always says he doesn't like quiche!  Note: I used half as much cheese as they recommended. I use a little bit of medium cheddar, parmesan, low fat mozerella and feta. Coconut oil was used instead the unhealthy vegetable oil. I used 3/4 package frozen spinach, 1/2 sweet onion, 6 oz sliced mushrooms, 1/2 bell pepper, satayed in coconut oil with a bit of white wine at the end cooked out. Spices added: sea salt, fresh ground pepper, a dash of nutmeg and a dash chili pepper. Enjoy!

My 20 year old son ate half of this quiche in one sitting! I did add two extra eggs, and 3 1/2 cups of havarati cheese. I like my salt, so added a 1/2 tsp. (+) salt. Used 8 cups of fresh spinach. By the time it sautes down you would've never known there were 8 cups to begin with. I also added sliced (long) grape tomatoes, cut side up to the top of mixture in pie pan. My son said that was why he loved this recipe so much. Amazing recipe. Side note-sauteed fresh mushrooms for those who wanted to add those on top of the already cooked quiche.

text:
This was exceptionally delicious!  I served it at a casual breakfast with friends and everyone loved it.  I don't eat wheat or gluten so this ha become my "go-to" quiche.  In fact I'm serving it next week for a Christmas brunch.  The bright green of the spinach makes it very festive.  I would recommend (as some others did) that you really drain the spinach well.   I used a clean kitchen towel lined with paper towels and poured the spinach in.  I then rolled it all up and twisted the towel to really squeeze out the extra liquid.  Worked like a charm!

text:
I doubled this in a 13 x 9 inch pan and cut into squares. It was a big hit at a brunch, with several requests for the recipe! I used margarine to saute the onions instead of veg. oil. & 16 oz of muenster for the double recipe. I added about 1/4 cup extra cheddar to add color, and then grated extra cheddar on the top. I also prepared it the night before, then baked it the next morning (allowing it to sit out 20 min prior to baking). I can't wait to try it with some additions such as mushrooms or black olives, but it's delicious as is!

text:
I love this recipe!  I make an entire pie then eat it for breakfast all week long.  It's a dieter's dream--I use reduced fat cheese and cut the cheese down to a cup and a half.  It's so delicious.  You get protein from your eggs and cheese, and you get plenty of healthy veggies with the spinach and onion.  I like to throw in a tomato or two as well for extra healthy measures.  It's very filling, and the way I make it, 1/4 of the entire pie only has 250 calories!!  That's a pretty big serving for 250 satisfing calories!  This is definitely one of my favorite recipes--go make one now!

text:
This was great!  Here are the changes I made:  (a) I only used 2 cups of cheese.  I used the Kraft Italian blend of 5 cheeses.  (b) To cut down on the cholesterol I used organic "egg beaters" (a carton of organic egg whites).  (c) I bought a big organic beefsteak tomato and sliced it thin and placed them on top of the quiche.  For me, possibly because I used organic egg whites, I had to bake the quiche for 20 minutes at 350 and then 10 minutes at 375.  This was great!  My husband, who LOVES meat, really really liked this dish.  I made spaghetti with meat sauce on the side so he would get his "meat fix" and he actually thought a tossed salad would have been better as a side dish.  Go figure!  But thanks for the great recipe, we will definitely be making it again and having the leftovers for dinner tonight.  We will probably warm up the leftovers in our toaster oven.

text:
I am so glad to add this recipe to my recipe box.I have some physical challenges that include not being able to stand for hours (max 10 minutes and that is a challenge) over a hot stove, so finding something yummy, easy, and quick is great. The other thing I see here is the endless ways you can adapt this recipe. It's basically vegetarian (but not vegan) and you are a meat lover? Add some meat-ham, bacon, even some spicy left over chicken or shrimp. Clean your fridge of leftover veggies. Do not like spinach? How about using broccoli?  Want to lighten it?  Try some non-fat or lowfat cottage cheese to replace some (1/3) of the cheese (did that-yummy). Too bland? Experiment with herbs and spices you think would work-also vary the types of cheese.  I add garlic, some red pepper flakes, basil. I, also, added a teaspoon or two of ground flax seed for more fiber. I had a friend over and asked  her if she wanted to have a taste of my new recipe. She was skeptical until she tasted it, then I had to send the recipe home with her. Thank you so much for an excellent offering.  I know this will be made frequently in our house. I especially love that you don't have the added fat, calories, and carbs of traditional quiche with a crust.

text:
One of my family's favorites!  We substitute broccoli on occasion for the spinach.  I usually have to double or triple it though since it's exactly enough for six (our family size) but they usually eat several pieces.  We never use muenster though, always shredded cheddar since that's what we have on hand.  We also add a package of bacon - which as my boys say, "Makes everything better!"  This also translates nicely without a lot of extra prep for my gluten/dairy/corn allergic son since I only have to change out the cheese for him at the last minute for non-dairy cheese.  And hen I'm truly feeling lazy, I use dried onions reconstituted in chicken broth.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-10-15T14:21:48.703
helpfulCount:
4
userID:
11613955
Display Name:
newcook
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
106
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe using fresh spinach.

My ingredients:
1 pound fresh spinach. washed and chopped.
5 cloves of garlic, minced.
7 scallions, chopped.
1/2 inch ginger, grated.
3 full cups of grated cheddar cheese.
5 large eggs, beaten.
1/4 cup milk.
3/4 tsp salt.
1 tsp cumin seeds.
1 tsp pepper.
1/2 tsp italian seasoning.
Pinch of onion salt, garlic salt, nutmeg, cheese jalapeno popcorn flavor. ( basically anything you feel will go well with spinach)
1 tbsp oil.

In a pan, heat the oil and add cumin seeds. when they crackle, add garlic and ginger. Once the raw smell of garlic goes away, add scallions. Saute for a minute and then add spinach. Cook till spinach is tender but not completely cooked. (At this point, there will be water in the pan from spinach. I took it off the flame and used a slotted spoon to pick the spinach. You may try cooking till the water evaporates, I was afraid of overcooking so I avoided.)

Now as directed by the original recipe, mixed the ingredients and poured in a 9.5 inch pie pan.(I know, 9.5 inch?? anchor hocking set)

Cook for 35 mins, but let it remain in the oven for another half hour before you serve. 

I garnished it will tomato slices and olives as an afterthought.

text:
Previous reviewers mentioned two main complaints with this recipe: (1) too bland, and (2) too cheesy, so I made some modifications.  I cooked six slices of bacon and then used a little of the grease to saute the onions, a couple cloves of garlic (new addition), and a bag of fresh spinach.  I salted and peppered to taste rather than measuring and added the crumbled bacon to the quiche.  I also used cheese that I had on hand - a combo of white cheddar and mozzarella - and although I did not measure, it probably came to less than three cups.  My vegetarian daughter refused to eat the quiche because of the bacon, but the rest of us enjoyed it.

I just made this quiche this morning for my lovely lady, and let me tell you it was bangin!  I added bacon because - even though we both need to fit into our wedding dresses in one wee little month - um, bacon is delicious.  Instead of muenster, I literally used whatever cheese I had in my fridge.  1/2 cup of parmesan & 2 cups of "mexican mix" which had monterey jack, cheddar, asiago and some other deliciousness.  Our slices were gobbled up in seconds.  I highly recommend this dish - quick & easy!

text:
I have made this at least 10 times, I'm not even joking. My fiancee loves this so much. It super easy to make and it tastes great, what more can you ask for? The only thing I will say is that this is NOT quiche, but rather a frittata. Quiche not only has no crust, but also is custard based (eggs and cream). Frittata has no cream or crust.

Display Name:
MrsChmerkovskiy
isPro:

83

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my favorite recipe for quiche, and it's the only quiche I make on a regular basis. You won't miss the crust with this, and why bother making a quiche with a crust when you can have it simple and delicious like this? This recipe is great as is, but it also serves as a good base recipe and you can alter it to your own tastes.  I up the eggs to 7, saute a yellow pepper with the onion, and add a generous sprinkle of nutmeg.  I shake the nutmeg on top once the vegetables and egg mixture are combined together, then I mix it all in until it's incorporated.  I would say I use about 1/4 t. to 1/2 t. of the nutmeg. It's so yummy!  Oh, and if you're feeling lazy and want to skip a step (or accidentally forget this step) don't fret about heating the spinach to get rid of the excess moisture.  If you wring it out well enough, it's not a big deal.  I forgot to heat it in the pan the last time I made it, and it still turned out fine.  Highly recommended!

This quickly became a family favorite. I like it better with a crust, but that is just personal preference. This was really good.  My first quiche and it came out great.  I brought this to a pot luck and every one wanted the recipe.  I used sausage links that I crumbled up and then used a Tbsp of the grease to cook the onions and used a 1/2 can of diced green chiles. Update! 
I made again and didn't change anything but the cheese amount and type and was a hit also.  I used a 2 cup bag of Mexican blend cheese.

text:
Excellent with a few changes I made on my own and from following the reviews. This is what I did.....I added an extra egg, a jar of well drained artichokes, 1 clove fresh garlic a dash of Worcestershire sauce, and some cottage cheese and parmesan cheese and diced butter cheese all instead of Muenster. It is MARVELOUS!! Very similar to our favorite spinach artichoke dip...only in the form of quiche. NOTE: make sure you squeeeze dry the spinach and drain the artichokes well! I also tried putting some into the microwave in a small glass bowl to bake and it worked great. Just microwave until it is cooked through. I think I did about 4-5 minutes for 2 cups of unbaked quiche. (Depends on your microwave.)

text:
I used this recipe as a base, but instead of spinach, onion, and muenster, I use all my leftover vegetables and a lesser amount (4-6 oz) of whatever cheese I want (usually smoked gouda).  I also add some skim milk to the beaten eggs.  This is a great recipe for using up leftover veggies, particularly if they've already been seasoned and cooked as some other side dish.  Just chop them up a bit and throw them in.  I was surprised how good it turned out.  Just make sure to choose a cheese you really like as it makes a huge difference.

text:
This was SUCH A PLEASANT dish! I used fresh spinach and heated it in a pan just enough to wilt it, then squeezed it dry in a towel and chopped into small pieces. Cooked the onion until soft then browned slightly, added the spinach and evaporated any juice. Followed remaining directions exactly, except didn’t have quite enough Muenster, so made up the difference with Smoked Gouda (about ½ cup).  Served at room temperature as a side dish.  This could easily (and proudly) stand as a main course.  Really EXCELLENT -- my guests gave it rave reviews!  Was served at a birthday dinner with Marinated Grilled Shrimp by Rachel and Grilled Portobello Mushrooms by Michael (also from this site and 5*****).

text:
Pretty tasty.  Had to cook for much longer than 30 minutes-- then again I used a small high pyrex dish.

Tips:  do not undercook onion; it's ok to double onion amount; add full salt amount if you are using cheddar/monterey cheese combo; add frozen artichoke pieces;  bake in shallow container; put tomato slices on the bottom of pan so you can flip it and have them on top.

text:
This recipe, without modifications, tasted like delicious scrambled eggs. Unfortunately, quiche calls for a custard composed of eggs and milk/cream. I would make this recipe again, but with modifications surrounding the custard. Also, remember to pass the custard through a strainer to ensure a thorough mix and preventing chunks of egg in the pie.

text:
I used a tiny 12 hole Bundt cake pan ( a bit smaller than most regular cupcake pan holes. The recipe made 12 with the recipe as follows. I didn't have frozen spinach so I took about 2/3 of the fresh packaged spinach I had and cooked it in water with some chopped mushrooms. Drained the lot of it once it was cooked down, then followed the recipe as stated,  I used Swiss cheese. I should mention that I did not have as much spinach into my batter as the recipe called for due to the fact that I was using fresh spinach cooked down, however I loved the way it came out and did not feel at all that there was not enough spinach once it was done. 350 degrees for only 25 minutes with the pan I had.

userID:
5192624
Display Name:
Kelly Parks Wagner

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2070196.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family LOVED this.  I used fresh spinach in mine.  The only thing I sauteed was the onion and I sauteed it in a little butter rather than oil (I know not as healthy).   We made two quiches: one with spinach and mushrooms, and one with spinach, mushrooms and bacon.  I used only 2 cups of shredded cheese and choose to use Colby Jack.  There was still plenty of cheese even though I cut the recipe by a cup.  I don't know if my 'large' eggs weren't large enough, but I used an extra egg and about a half of a cup of milk (I didn't measure).  Because of how I beat the eggs (with a hand mixer), it was really light and fluffy.  It's a very versatile quiche.  I ended up cooking it closer to an hour (about 50 minutes( as thirty minutes wasn't nearly enough.  I'm thinking it was the extra stuff in that made it need to be cooked longer.  Definitely a keeper!!!!

Pretty good. I started prepping to make this and discovered that I didn't have the box of spinach in the freezer that I thought I did, so I made sort of a 'clean out the crisper' version, using some bell peppers and some wilty kale. I subbed in cheddar and parm for the muenster, since that was what I had on hand, and I baked the whole thing in the cast iron skillet that I sauteed the veggies in. Since it was still hot, my quiche was ready quicker! A nice, easy breakfast recipe.

userID:

Display Name:
cjbjones
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was amazing!  My husband had seconds and wanted to have the leftovers again the next night instead of freezing it (both of those things rarely happen!), and my 10 month old daughter loved it too.  Following other reviews, here is now I made it: Put frozen spinach in colander, ran with hot water until unfrozen, then squeezed out as much water as I could; sauteed onion, then added 2 chopped green onions (6 stems) and spinach to pan, continuing to cook on medium heat to evaporate remaining water from spinach; combined 5 eggs, only two cups Kraft mixed cheddar cheese (the kind that is made with Philadelphia cream cheese, it really made the quiche creamy), 1/4 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp black pepper, 1/4 tsp garlic powder (I love garlic, if you don't, you may not want to use as much) and 1/8 cup whole milk (could vary this depending on taste); added in the spinach mixture and mixed it thoroughly.  I baked this in a 9 inch metal cake pan sprayed with pam.  It cooked perfectly at 350 in 30 minutes.  I would highly recommend the cake pan over a pie dish as I think the quiche baked more evenly than when I have tried with a pie dish.  I really couldn't recommend this recipe more.  Enjoy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Crustless Spinach Quiche Haiku: "Low carbers rejoice! Loaded with eggy-veggie, this is so awesome!" This recipe is very close to something that I make on a weekly basis (5 eggs beaten w/ a variety of veggies and baked in muffin tins for a quick, portioned breakfast), but I wanted a dish more "polished" in appearance to serve for brunch guests. I used 2 packed cups of fresh spinach, and added diced red bell pepper (for some color), as well as some ham, a pinch of nutmeg and a heavy splash of milk. It looked beautiful, and tasted just as good at room temperature. The wonderful part of this recipe is its limitless potential for different ingredients, which is why it's no less than 5-stars!

text:
This was my first quiche-like recipe. It was delicious. I loved it, and so did my husband and 16 month old son, neither of which I can ever get to eat eggs willingly. But this was at least as much vegetable as it was egg, so it won cheers all around. I love how adaptable it is, too, because I can just use what I have around the house. I used 2 cups of cheese instead of 3, and 6 eggs instead of 5, cooked for 30 minutes at 350, and cooled for 10 minutes before cutting. I also added mushrooms, garlic, and most of a red pepper. I am really proud of how it came out. I cut the leftovers into portions and put half in the freezer and half in the fridge. I plan to make this maybe once a week with alterations to keep it interesting. A definite keeper!

Edit: 10/7  

Made this again tonight using Parmesan cheese (only 1 cup), adding a cup of cooked salmon, and sliced mushrooms.

I baked one in a pie dish and the other in an 8x8 square so I can freeze portion-size squares for a quick breakfast option.  

This quiche is definitely a regular at our house!  You can do so much with it!

I agree that this is a great low-carb dish. I just used 2 cups of cheese and it was plenty--and this is someone who loves cheese. :-) I also stirred in some milk to the egg mixture, like I was making an omelette. Save a dish: I cooked the onions and spinach in an ovenproof 14" skillet that could accomodate the whole dish. text:
I've tried a lot of recipes on this site and this quiche is at the top of my favorites list! Two ironies:  1) I was never a big fan of quiche before now.  2) I modified it to make it lower in fat... usually doing this makes it taste less than amazing, but not the case here.  I calculated the ingredients to 9 servings because I had a 16 oz bag of frozen spinach on hand and wanted to use it all. Instead of using the 4 1/2 cups of muenster cheese, I used 2 cups of shredded reduced-fat pepper jack cheese, 1 cup lowfat cottage cheese, and 1/2 cup parm cheese. I also added broccoli (2 stalks, no stems) and about 4 oz of chopped mushrooms. Like others recommended, I scooped most of the mix into a muffin tray. There was some mixture leftover so I baked it in a tiny casserole dish.   Everyone loved it!

country:
None
text:
This recipe is almost identical to one I have been making for years. However, I do not bake mine. I cook it initially on the gas hob on a low flame until the eggs are just starting to set - without burning the base; I have a stainless steel pan which is perfect for this. Then I add the cheese - usually homemade feta or haloumi - sprinkled on top and place under a preheated gas grill until set and lightly browned. I also add a dash of nutmeg and mushrooms (and anything I have which I feel like adding to the initial saute) as per other reviewers. Very useful dish especially for a quick lunch. Living on a farm, we have our own veggies; this dish is very versatile so I can always find something in season in the garden to add apart from spinach - Swiss chard also works well as long as it is freshly harvested.

text:
I made this quiche for company as a labor day "brunch" item. It was a huge hit. It proves you do not need crust. I took some tips from others and cut the cheese to 2 cups using 1 1/4c organic shredded cheddar and 3/4c ff cottage cheese. The cottage cheese gives a more creamy texture. To cut some more calories I used 3 egg beaters and 2 organic eggs. I sauteed the leeks ( little zestier than onions), fresh organic spinach and arugala chopped, and shitake mushroms in Organic Pam with some chopped garlic. Seasoning the mixture with red pepper flakes, ground lemon pepper and garlic powder puts in the final touch. I suggest serving it with a freshly baked breakfast bread ( I baked apple/cinnamon) and a fresh fruit salad. This will wow your guests.

userID:
2891565
Display Name:
kkish
isPro:

followersCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I doubled this recipe for Easter brunch and it was a huge hit.  Followed some previous suggestions like adding a generous splash of milk or 1/2 and 1/2 and using less of the spinach and about a cup less of the cheese.  If you follow the original recipe exactly, you get a very dense, spinach heavy quiche.  The milk and less cheese give it a lighter, and fluffier texture more like a true quiche (in my opinion) should be.  I also added sundried tomatoes and a cup of frozen (but thawed) artichoke hearts for added color and flavor.  Like another reviewer, I thought thinly sliced tomatoes on top added nice presentation.  This is a very easy dish to prepare even if you aren't much of a cook.  If you use a glass pan as I did, be sure to grease it well with plenty of butter as the quiche will stick otherwise.

text:
Perfect! 5 star taste and texture, especially after I added some garlic powder to the spinach. Very nice in its simplicity, I wouldn't go adding lots of stuff to it. My quiche dish is quite large so this came out quite thin but it's not a huge problem. It'll make it easy to double the recipe if necessary. As it stands, I think it feeds 3 people as a main cours. UPDATE: Here's a nice idea for the leftovers. I cut a poppy seed bagel in half, toasted and buttered the top, layered the bottom wih squares of the quiche (as I said, mine was very thin) and cheese and toasted it in the oven. Put the two halves back together and ate it with garden tomatoes on the side. It was great!

text:
EXCELLENT RECIPE, especially for low-carb dieters.  You won't even miss the crust!  I added some mushrooms, which were sauteed with the onions ahead of time to remove excess moisture.  I also added some crumbled bacon to the bottom of the pie pan before scooping the egg mixture in.  To compensate for the extra ingredients, I added 2 extra eggs.  It was FANTASTIC!  Muenster is the PERFECT cheese for this recipe because of its creamy texture and subtle flavor.  You must try it!  To find shredded Muenster is impossible (it is usually only sold in slices).  However, you can go to the deli section of your grocery store to ask them to cut off a 1-lb. "brick" of Muenster for you.  It's worth the effort.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love, love, LOVE this recipe!! I like to follow a recipe exactly as it is written the first time I make it, THEN decide if I want to make any changes the next time I prepare it. This is an excellent recipe as it is written; simple, delicious and definitely a keeper! One of the reasons I love this recipe is because it is so easy to "mix it up" by changing the vegetable and cheese combinations. Be versatile and choose a combination of ingredients based on your preferences....broccoli, mushrooms, bacon, etc. The second time I made this recipe, I did make changes based simply on MY preferences and dietary habits. I used olive oil to saute the onion and fresh spinach (although frozen is just fine). I substituted the  Muenster cheese with 2 cups of Monterey Jack cheese and 1 cup of Pepper Jack cheese (grating the cheese rather than using pre-packaged) to give it a bit of a kick. I have made and shared this recipe with many, many people because not only is it delicious, but also because everyone loves the simplicity and flexibility of this recipe. I also usually double the recipe so there will be left-overs to reheat for a hurried Monday morning breakfast :)

text:
Delicious - I did not like to saute the onions first - I like them to have a bit of crunch.  I added some Italian herbs and crushed red chilies as well as a red jalapeno.  You do not need to add any salt.  The cheese has enough salt for the dish.  I used a blend of organic cheddar cheeses - feta would be really good too. Fresh spinach works well just saute and allow to cool. I also wanted to serve this in square pieces with more height so I added an extra egg and baked it in a square glass 8x8 baking dish. Worked great! Easy

Great base recipe! city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This quiche was excallent, IMO.  I ended up using less cheese (probably only used two cups, which was just right for us).  I also added 1/4 C milk, like another poster suggested.  This made the quiche moister and fluffier.  I used cupcake liners and a cupcake pan to bake (same temperature and time as suggested) and they were the perfect size portions.  I made this for brunch and it was a great menu item, and easy for kids to serve themselves, and the adults loved them too.  One last thought, next time I make these in the cupcake liners, I would spray a little cooking spray to the papers, as they did stick just a little bit.  Overall, LOVED this recipe and will make it again.

text:
The spinach amount was perfect.  I baked them in a Duncan Hines mini loaf pan/brownie pan (each loaf is about 2.5 x 3.75). I love the pan because it's like a muffin pan but there are 8 mini loaves instead.  The mini quiches baked up perfectly, not too much spinach at all and they are a great size for breakfast.  I doubled the recipe and made it with eggbeaters and light sharp cheese, it made 10 filled to the rim mini loaves that are about 288 calories each and are perfectly filling with just one.

text:
I love this recipe! I've tweaked it a bit, but that's what's so great about this recipe you can change it to suit you and what you like. I changed the cheese to Italian shredded cheese mix, added basil, cilantro, garlic, mushrooms, bell peppers, breakfast sausage, and whatever else I feel like, as long as it all fits in the pan. It's always a big hit, even one picky guest turned it down because she doesn't like spinach but after taking a bite from a friend's plate she went back for her own piece. I like to serve it Christmas morning when the family is over for presents, especially with red bell peppers in it so it has a festive red and green look to it.

country:
None
text:
I just made this recipe, and it is, as the others here have said, delicious and very adaptable. I used 1.5 packs of frozen spinach, because I love the green stuff. I added some shitake mushrooms, about half of a green pepper, and a hint more salt. I didn't have Muenster, so I used about 2.25 cups of shredded low fat mozza-cheddar cheese, and a few crumbles of feta.  

I placed the mixture in 6 jumbo muffin tins over night and baked them this morning. I had a bit more moisture than I should have (my fault), so I baked for maybe 10 more minutes than stated. These were perfect! And they would certainly be ideal for sharing...should they last that long.

userID:
274946
Display Name:
MOOCHIA
isPro:

1

19

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Foolproof, easy, and delicious.

The Husband loves spinach, and one of our frequent breakfast guests is a no-carbs kind of guy.  Thus, this is my go-to breakfast for both of them.  It's super easy to make...in fact, I usually make it the night before (all but the cooking), cover it in foil and store it in the fridge.  Those who choose to follow this example would do well to take it out of the fridge about 15-20 before cooking or to leave it in the oven a little longer.  

Many sorts of cheese work.  I often go for a jack/cheddar blend.

I also usually add a handful or two of diced ham (a cup or so).  Diced Canadian bacon or sausage also works.  I've also been known to toss in some sliced black olives.

One of the most enjoyable things about this dish is that leftovers can be saved and served...either warmed up or cold.  

This one's a keeper!
Review:

5

text:
Great for the low-carbers out there! This recipe is so versatile. I usually add in some minced carrots and cubed ham, use a 2-cup bag of shredded colby-jack cheese (our favorite), use a full 16-oz bag of thawed and squeezed frozen chopped spinach. If needed, I'll add more egg (Eggbeaters and egg whites are great, too), and will just shake in extras of garlic powder, salt and pepper. Onion powder also works. We eat this weekly!

This recipe is fantastic.  I did a few things differently and I just love the flavor.  I used olive oil in place of vegetable oil, 1/2 a chopped red onion, only 4 eggs, 1/2 a red bell pepper and 1/2 a yellow bell pepper chopped, and 2 cups mixture of shredded sharp cheddar and shredded taco cheese.  I also did a few shakes of onion powder and garlic powder. This recipe is SO easy and has great flavor, and is so colorful when using the bell peppers!  Definitely one of my new favorite breakfast dishes.

THIS. WAS. FABULOUS! Easy to make & bake, and dissapeared in one day in my 2 person household! (My boyfriend ate nothing else yesterday; I made 3 of his favorite dishes and all he ate was this quiche!) I had to substitute cheeses b/c I goofed & was out of muenster. I used 1 1/2 c swiss, 1/4 c mozzerella/provelone mix, and 1 1/4 c reduced fat cheddar. I will be making this over and over and over again so I look forward to using munster, but this recipe is as forgiving as it is EXCELLANT!!! Less than 24 hours later, I 'm making another one now.  **UPDATE** I've made this several times with many variations on cheese & even adding crab meat. Tastey & forgiving as long as you have 3 c of some kind of shredded cheese. :) Fantastic.

text:
Really great flavor and so easy to put together. I added some nutmeg because I really like that with spinach. I used less cheese - maybe just 2 cups - a mixture of Italian blend & Sharp Cheddar because that's what I had on hand. 

My only complaint is that I tried to make these bite size by using a mini-muffin tin (recipe turns out 32 mini quiches). Even though I have a non-stick pan and used PAM spray, they were still very difficult to remove and the presentation suffered. If I made them again, I would use this filling with a crust.

Made this in muffin pan as other reviewers suggested. Perfection!! I used a cup of low fat cottage cheese and 1 cup half mozarella and sharp cheddar (mistake!) and also 1/4 cup parmesan. I made a diet friendly version of this that turned out great. I used egg beaters, and reduced fat cheese (try some of the pre-shredded kraft or sargento ones from the grocery store). text:
Great, versatile recipe!  To make it a bit healthier I used 4 eggs and 1 egg white, 1 cup each of 2% sharp cheddar and mozzerella, and some garlic to the half of an onion I had.  I also diced up a lone roma tomato I had and added that to the spinach mixture when it was almost ready to combine with the eggs and cheese.  I served it with Fluffy Whole Wheat Biscuits from this site.  A definite keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this a few times with slightly less cheese and it always comes out great! I used FRESH spinach (trimmed of stems of course) by sautéing w/ a tiny bit of olive oil and with the onions (saute onions first!).  Then, I put it on a plate to cool. Once cool, I gently squeeze out some of the juice and add to the egg and cheese mixture. Then I add 1 teaspoon of flour.  I think this helps keep the quiche from being "watery." I've found frozen spinach to come out watery a few times (but if you squeeze it enough it will be fine).  My mother suggested that I use melted butter to coat the glass pan and sprinkle w/ parmesan before adding the egg mixture.  I liked that idea.  If you use a smoked cheese like smoked gouda, it gives the quiche a meat-like flavor that I like.  A tip of what not to do (in my opinion) is add black olives--- I usually

I loved this recipe. I read some of the suggestions and it came out perfect. I added chopped baby Bella mushrooms and chopped jalopenos when I sauteed the onions. I used 1/2 box of frozen spinach, about 1 cup of muenster cheese and about 2 tbsp of shreddded parm cheese. I also added cooked bacon and chopped tomatoes before baking. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious. Although I'm sure the original recipe is excellent, I too made a couple of changes, like some of the other contributors. Perhaps these helped because of cooking at high altitude (New Mexico).   At the last minute, I decided to add about 1/2 cup cooked brown rice to the mixture, which seemed a little too moist, and it really did the job of adjusting the texture. I also grated about 1/4 cup of Romano cheese and mixed it with 1/4 cup of seasoned breadcrumbs, and sprinkled the mixture on top of the dish before baking. The result was a slightly crunchy and very tasty golden crust. My family and I really enjoyed this dish.

This was a great and easy recipe, we really enjoyed it. I used egg beaters and I skipped the onions since I don't like them. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5727430.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an easy to doctor recipe.  I followed another user's suggestion and put these in muffin tins...I was able to add cheese on top to half and not put cheese at all in the other half, to knock out some calories and for those that were lactose intolerant.  I also used fresh spinach, which I thought gave it a nicer flavor.  For the ones with cheese on top, I added the cheese to melt the last 7 - 10 minutes or, cooking them in the muffin tins for a total of 20 minutes.  I also threw some low-fat turkey smoked sausage in there to give it a little more of a savory taste.  So half the folks got a vegetarian dish, while the other half had "breakfast".  Oh!  And I also used 6 egg whites instead of the whole eggs.  Trying to keep it light before swimsuit season, for those that are counting calories!

I'm making low fat recipes, so this one is perfect.  I love the other quiche recipes on this site (Clark's quiche is the best), but the crust, bacon, creme ect. is too much.  This one is perfect and surprisingly tasty.  I used low-fat old cheddar (about a cup) and Parmesean Reggiano.  Because they're strong cheeses you only need a bit, so that decreases the fat drastically.  I'll make this one again.

I like it better than any quiche I've had before!  UPDATE: So, I've been playing around with this recipe.  I have doubled it for a "pan" of quiche, and it tasted way too spinach-y or something.  I merely doubled the recipe, so I was confused by that.  Also, I tried using reduced-fat cheese once, and it just wasn't nearly as good.  Finally, adding about five strips of cooked, chopped bacon makes it taste even better!

Loved this recipe!  So easy!!  I did add about 2 to 3 cloves fresh minced garlic to the onion.  I cooked these in butter (always better when cooking eggs ) and after adding the spinach I added fresh ground nutmeg and pepper.  I also added 6 eggs instead of 5. text:
My roommate and I had a huge tub of fresh spinach that we needed to get rid of before it went bad, so we decided to make a quiche. This one was surprisingly easy to make. Since we didn't have the pre-packaged frozen spinach, we finished off what we had, which was probably between 3 and 4 cups chopped. We also eyeballed the amount of cheese, and instead of Muenster we used mozzarella and cheddar. Didn't measure the salt and pepper, or oil either (tend not to measure things exactly when cooking). We did use the same amount of onion and followed the actual cooking instructions and bake time. It turned out delicious and will probably make again. Also, would like to try recipe in a pie crust.

A really tasty and easy low carb/lower fat meal.  To cut down on cholesterol, I used 3 whole eggs and 6T. egg whites from a carton (equal to 2 eggs).  I added 2 cloves of crushed garlic, diced ham and canned mushrooms.  I also cut the cheese to 2 cups, using 1c. part skim mozzarella and 1c. sharp cheddar.  My husband & I loved it!

Awfully good and very easy! I did take some liberties (ideas from other reviewers) and add slivered ham and some sharp white cheddar instead of the cheese called for. Also, because I had about 1/3 cup of light sour cream that I either needed to use or toss, I whisked that into the egg mixture too.

My 6 year-old son peeked at the finished product and said, "I don't think I'll like that." I served him the tiniest serving - so he could at least try it - and he ended up taking another HUGE serving. Thanks for this keeper of a recipe!

text:
Really great base recipe!  We ended up adding some crab meat, scallions, and feta cheese that needed to be eaten.  It turned out fantastic!  Really great texture and consistency.  You really don't miss or  need the crust.  Next time I will try a swiss, ham and green pepper mixture in addition to the spinach.  If you use a salty cheese (like feta) you may want to cut back on the salt.  Since I added so many extra ingredients I had to use a deep dish pan and cook at 400 degrees.

Really good. I made a couple changes. 3 cups of Muenster is alot of cheese, so I reduced it to 1 cup of sharp white cheddar instead and added deli thin slices of Muenster on top of the quiche. It made a really nice top crust. Instead of 5 eggs, I used 3 whole eggs and 3 egg whites to cut down on fat and cholestorol.  I also sauteed crushed garlic along with the onion. We served it with a greek salad!

YUM! I completely changed the recipe since I didn't have the proper ingredients and it was sooo good! I didn't have muenster so I used one ball of fresh mozzerella (in water) shredded into the egg mixture, and also fresh shredded hard parm in there (didn't measure). I will definitely make this again for brunch guests!

This turned out okay, but not as written.  Entirely too much cheese and onion is called for.  These over quantities are easily seen during the preparation compared to amount of spinach.  I took away at least half of my chopped onion and cheese and crossed my fingers.  Entertaining a work associate for dinner tonight and I was delighted to find the cooking time and temperature suggested produced a very solid quiche with good flavor.

text:
I have made spinach quiche many times but always used a crust. I decided to try this simple recipe. I always use nutmeg and never use salt as the cheese is salty enough; that’s the only change I made.  Because it’s Crustless,  I decided to use a 9in square Pyrex dish. I usually use either cheddar or Swiss cheese. This time I used extra sharp cheddar and Swiss cheese.  It’s delicious but! I took the picture after I had a taste.

text:
I used this as the base but really modified it from there - I used bacon, cut down the spinach by at least half and added brown mushrooms. I cooked the bacon then cut into small pieces. Sautéed garlic, onions, frozen spinach (about 10oz) and diced mushrooms. I mixed all this in with 10 eggs, 2 cups cheese (mozzarella and marbled cheddar) and some milk. Baked as per the directions given in muffin moulds. This recipe got me about 20 muffins. They turned out spectacular!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve been making this quiche for years, this recipe used to be on a gluten free recipe board. 

Here’s what I do, I use farm fresh pastured eggs  from a local organic farm, huge difference in taste. I use organic super greens, organic cilantro, & organic sweet onion, I sauté them in raw butter from grass fed cows, I under cook the greens since they’re going to be baked in the quiche. I use organic sharp cheddar cheese instead Munster, only because organic cheddar is easier to find. I use the same raw butter to grease the baking dish, then top the quiche with sliced organic heirloom tomatoes before popping it into the oven. So worth it to go organic. I don’t skimp on the fat either, it’s good fat, and we love it

text:
I chop up mini red, yellow and orange peppers and 1 red onion. I sauté this with  about a tsp of minced garlic. Then . I add 1 package of fresh spinach.  I've used any kind of hard cheese. ( no feta or goat or cream cheeses). I have also used canned and frozen spinach, just squeeze it very dry then chop it up with a sharp knife. I pour it into mini greased muffin tins. I cook in between 20 to 30 minutes. (I check it with a toothpick) it comes out perfect every time.

I didn't realize you could make a crustless quiche and not lose the taste!  I used almost a full bag of fresh spinach and added other vegetables: broccoli, mushrooms and peppers, zucchini,tomatoes.  I didn't measure my ingredients. Once in a rush I used onion powder.  I doubled the s & p, and added a bit of Italian seasoning. The mix doesn't need to reach the top of the pie plate. text:
First time making quiche. I looked at other reviews for additional guidance and added dashes of Italian seasoning, adobo seasoning, and garlic power, and a splash of milk and used about 1 1/2 cups cheddar cheese, since I didn't have Muenster. Served with tossed salad, but could have eaten it alone. I agree about not missing the crust. And a "this was good, Mom" from my picky 18 year old son was 'the icing on the cake' for me.  Will definitely be making this again and again. Can't wait to try other ingredient combinations.

text:
I make this all the time, for a low carb dinner. I have made the recipe as written. Occasionally, I have to use whatever cheese I have on hand and I use butter instead of vegetable oil. It is always good. It is more "spinachy" and less "eggy". I like it that way. Also, I like to use a square casserole dish instead of a pie pan. I prefer it cut in squares. I make this three or four times a month. That is how much we like it.

4

text:
Very good. This recipe is pretty flexible. I made it more healthy by using 1.5 cups low fat cottage cheese and 1.5 cups mozzarella instead of the muenster. I have also made it with double the spinach. Just make sure the spinach is pretty dry before mixing in, or you run the risk of a soggy quiche.

Loved it!  Switched it up with what I had on hand.  Used broccoli & cheddar cheese.  Also added red & yellow peppers to the onion sauté!!!  Yummy!!!!  UPDATE! 11/1/14  I'm trying to watch my weight but wanted this because it was so good.  Lowered the calories this way….Again I used red and yellow peppers along with the onions and sautéed them with cooking spray rather than the oil.  Used 2 cps of cheese (I use cheddar) instead of 3.  Used 2 eggs and 6 egg whites.  I also used cooked broccoli instead of spinach.   I used a glass pyrex pie plate and cooked it for 40 min.  Delish… sweet and savory!!!

text:
This was my first quiche.  My mother is gluten intolerant and this came out great.  I would suggest cooking at 375.  I baked at 350 and had to keep it in for an extra 15-20 mins because the middle was still loose.  I cooked up raw spinach that I cut up after I sautéed the onions.  I added 1/4c. milk to the egg mixture along with some ground nutmeg.  I used cheddar cheese and will definitely use a different kind of cheese next time.  I topped it off with sliced tomatoes and spindled park cheese on the top.  I will have this for breakfast every morning.  A+++

I made little mini quiches to bring to Christmas dinner at my bf's aunt and uncle's. His uncle has a gluten intolerance, so was looking to bring something he could eat. This was a big hit with everybody. I did add some mushrooms I happened to have around, but I've made it by the book too and it's great both ways. One thing to note, if you make minis, be sure to grease your muffin tin well, a full size one is easy enough to deal with using the pie cutter, but you can't get anything like that in the muffin tin if some cheese gets stuck on.

This was great!  I usu use a diff recipe (w/ a crust) from All-recipes however I am looking to cut carbs!  I doubled recipe & put into a 9X13 as suggested from another.  This amount was right for my family of 5 (3 teenage athletic girls). I used egg beaters bc I was curious if it would taste different, and was surprised this tasted so good! Thumbs up by everyone - husband didn't like sausage.

country:

text:
With a little tweaking to meet our tastes this turned out great.  I used 2 cups of Swiss cheese and 1/2 cup of Parmesan cheese in place of the Muenster.  I also added some sliced baby bella mushrooms and garlic in with onions and spinach.  I didn't notice at the time, but my pkg. of spinach was 12 oz. instead of 10 which was way too much spinach.  I think next time I'll either add some additional eggs and bake in a larger dish or cut back on the spinach a bit as I thought it was a little much.  Will definitely add another clove of garlic next time as well.

text:
One of my favorite recipes on this site. I've been on Atkins for over a year, and this makes a great low-carb breakfast or lunch! I usually use shredded cheddar instead of Muenster because I can buy it in bulk - it tastes great no matter what cheese you use though. I also add some Feta cheese when I have it. I also like to add a cup of sour cream - if you're trying to eat low-fat or low-calorie I wouldn't recommend this, but it gives the quiche a nice texture! That being said, I still think this recipe is perfect as written! I make it at least twice a month.

text:
Frozen spinach always tastes "fishy" to me.  You can substitute a pound and a half fresh spinach for the 10 oz frozen, which will cook down rapidly to the right amount in about the same time it takes to evaporate the liquid from the frozen.  Add it at the same step in this recipe and pull it when well wilted.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A great 'starter' recipe. I changed the spinach to broccoli - about 2 cups or more (lightly steamed and chopped to get some of the moisture content out). I've also added a 6th egg - changed the cheese to Pepper Jack and a small handful of fresh Parmesean. Added 1 or 2 cloves of minced garlic, crumbled bacon bits, a small amount of chopped turkey deli meat (less fat than ham - but ham is good too), a tbsp or so of cream cheese (melted first), and I sauteed the onion with some fresh mushrooms too - I used 'baby bellas'. You have to put the pie plate on a cookie sheet - it might bubble up a bit and keeps the oven cleaner. I also increased the cook time by 5 min due to the added amount of items and the extra egg.

Review:

userID:
2414705
Display Name:
Miss Carr
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really easy and sooo tasty! Like other reviewers have said, I basically used what I had in my fridge.
I had a bag of fresh, organic baby spinach that I needed to use up, so I washed and sliced up the spinach and sauteed it with the onions. Along with the onions, I added chopped garlic and crushed red pepper and sauteed until soft, then added spinach and sauteed until wilted. Put in a colander and squeezed all the water out until dry. I also seasoned the spinach mixture with a little bit of salt and pepper.
With the eggs, I added about a 1/4 cup soy milk, some chopped black olives and the cheeses I used were: Mediterranean style feta cheese, cheddar cheese, mozzarella, parmesan, pepper jack, and a mexican blend. Sounds like a lot, but I just put a small amount of each to make about 2 1/2 cups.
Poured into a greased 8x8 glass pan, and put some sliced tomatoes on top with sliced nacho-style jalapenos in the middle of each tomato.
The aromas coming from the oven...OMG!
I had to add 10 more minutes to the time and set the oven to 325 because the middle was still a little wet when I inserted a toothpick.
The addition of the pepper jack and tomatoes were delish!

text:
This was so, so easy and delicious! I bought the HUGE bag of fresh spinach at our local warehouse store and searched for recipes to use it up. It was absolute fantastic as is, but I think next time I might try making it in muffin cups and freeze the "quiche muffins" for a quick and healthy breakfast.  I did use Muenster cheese, but could only find sliced, so I just chopped it up. Honestly, I think any cheese would work just fine.  Will definitely make again and again!

text:
I make this once a week or so.  I have changed it to our liking.  I omit the onion.  I typically like onion, but in this recipe it is overpowering.  I use 7 eggs to make it go a bit further.  I use 2 cups of cheese, usually the mexican mix.    I add either 1 cup of sliced mushrooms or 1 cup of chopped ham.  I add the ham or mushrooms to the spinach and saute it together.  Even my 2 year old will eat it.

text:
What a great recipe! I've made it in a 9-inch pie pan, and also in muffin tins. I followed other reviewer's suggestions and cut down on the amount of cheese used (10oz) and I used a combination of the cheeses that I had in the fridge. I sub'd bacon for the vegetable oil (because bacon makes everything better) and I added 1/8 tsp. of nutmeg. Muffins take about 20 minutes to cook.

text:
I live a low carb lifestyle and just love this recipe!  The first time I made it the only substitution I made was (1) small carton of cheese and chive eggbeaters and I used cheddar vs. muenster.  I added a few dashes of tabasco as well. So good.  I took another reader's suggestion and put them in muffin tins sprayed with non-stick spray.  It makes 12 perfect egg muffins.  Next time, I used sauted green onion, ham chunks and swiss cheese.  Amazing.  I love that one container of egg beaters makes 12 perfect little snacks.  I refrigerate them and take to work for breakfast or lunch.  My kids love them too.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this quiche for brunch today.  We had a gluten free guest.  I served it with cut up fruit, bagels, and smoked salmon as part of a nice spread.  I thought this quiche was very good.  I admit, I did miss the pie crust for texture reasons, but I thought this came out great.  I prepared it mostly as written.   These are the changes:

I used a 2 cup bag of shredded sharp cheddar (I couldn't find shredded muenster and didn't want to shred it myself).

I used about 1/4 cup of grated parmesan to kind of make up the difference for my cheese shortage.

I added in a chopped garlic clove, a pinch of nutmeg, and 1/4 cup of milk.

This was really tasty and can be made many different ways.  Even the men loved it.  This will be featured again on my brunch rotation.  This can be made with ingredients that most people have on hand, which is nice.

text:
So easy and delicious! This always satisfies me and its a great way to get spinach into my diet. I have tried this recipe in muffin form, and the quiche always sticks to the wrappers or the muffin tray. I would recommend making it in a regular glass baking dish and cutting into the size pieces you want. This recipe freezes and reheats really well, although it never lasts more than a few weeks!

Good base recipe, but needs more "stuff" to make it worth repeating. Used 6 eggs and a combination of muenster, baby swiss, and sharp white cheddar cheeses. Added diced green olives, sun-dried tomatoes, reduced onion to 1/2, and sliced fresh tomatoes on top.  Now THAT was incredible! It was juicy, tender, and sooo much flavor. Doubled recipe and cooked in 9x12 pyrex, had to almost double cooking time as a result. Served cut in squares for a baby shower - rave reviews!

text:
Didn't make it as directed(which I'm sure is wonderful as well). But giving it 5 stars because of it's diversity! To use a healthier version: I sub. 1 1/2 cup egg beaters in place of the eggs, steamed fresh spinach(just becuase we had it), added very small heads of broccoli and diced celery(yummy), for the cheese mixture, I used 1 cup low fat cottage cheese, 1 cup fat free shredded cheddar, 1/4 cup regular shredded cheddar. Added tomotatoes to the top(a must).  It was GREAT! I will be trying diced ham next. Can't wait!

text:
I was in search for a spinach dish because I had a bunch of fresh spinach from my mother. I was so glad I found this recipe. My family loved it! Since I didn't have canned spinach, I had wilted them in the microwave (in a large bowl fill it with spinach;1/4 cup of water;cover it well with a plate & make sure it's not resting on the spinach; microwave for 3-4 minutes;transfer to colander;press w/ a spatula to release excess liquid). I also used half parmesan and mozzarella because that's what I had and still turned out fabulous!!

text:
This recipe rocks. It'd be great as is, but I used a bag of Trader Joe's shredded smoked cheeses (Gouda, Mozzarella, Cheddar, Provolone mix) and that smokiness really gave it a delightful twist. I also chopped fresh spinach, because I have a HUGE bag from Costco that needs to be used. I've never been a crust person, pie or quiche or otherwise, so I love that this has all the good stuff without the wasted calories of crust. We make up for it by topping it with sour cream (though plain yogurt would be good and less fat). I used three eggs and two eggs worth of Egg Beaters, because that's what I had. Best of all, my anti-green vegetable 2-1/2 year old ate as much of it as I did. Woo-hoo!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/162918.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i like how this quiche is crustless as i am always looking at ways to make recipes healthier. some changes: used under 1TBSP of the oil as it wasnt necessary in my non-stick pan; added mushrooms, 1/2 red pepper, 1/2cup soy milk (that's all i had), 1 tsp basil, left over ham, and reduce the cheese to 1 cup soy cheddar and 1 cup lite mozzarella. i bake for 35min but i think i couldve left it in for another 5min. the quiche was very light and had a nice blend of flavors. it's a nice basic recipe that you can modify to suit your own taste. i definitely didnt feel guilty devouring this!

I normally use a 16 ounce bag of spinach and sometimes I use a little less cheese (half to 2/3 the amount called for). It's also very, very easy to make.

text:
Very good. I used olive oil and added a red bell pepper, 2 big cloves of garlic, and half a shallot after the spinach.  I would add the garlic sooner next time and maybe use a little less - I love garlic, but it was definitely present as a flavor.  I also added 1/2 c milk to the eggs.  Used two heaping cups of cheese - one part-skim mozz and one of italian blend.  Finally, I added a shake or two of nutmeg.  I baked in the 350-375 range for 40 minutes.  Perfect!  I might add bacon next time, but this way is healthier and still really tasty!

text:
WOW - thats all I can say! I was thinking, this sounds easy and its a quiche, I can throw this together for dinner and it will be fine. But, I threw it together and served it and everyone couldnt get enough! Everyone at the dinner gave RAVE reviews, and there were people saying how if they werent so stuffed they could just devour the whole thing... Very pleasantly surprised at how well this went over. The cahnges I made - put in about 1/2 c crumbled apple cinnamon sausage, used the extra sharp low fat cheddar, and egg substitute.  I didnt drain the spinach, and I used frozen pepper & onion blend. I nixed the oil (due to the sausage) and I just cooked it down until the pan was ready to be de-glazed. I will definitely make this again, if you're considering trying this recipe, GO FOR IT! :) Thank you so much for sharing this with us all!

Fantastic!  I will definately make this again!  Variations as follows:  Instead of the 3c cheese, I used 1/2 c sharp cheddar + 1 c ff cottage cheese + 1/4 c parmesean.  I also added a small can of diced green chiles (but will toss in a few jalepenos next time to kick it up a notch) and tomatoes.  Also thinking some feta and pinenuts would be yummy!  I didn't have a pie pan so I used my 9x9 square and had to bake it 10 extra minutes.  Ate the leftovers for lunch and dinner today!

The flavors were yummy.  I added mushrooms in with the onions and then chopped cooked ham with the spinach.  I used 8 oz. of colby jack cheese because I couldn't find Muenster (I probably didn't look hard enough).  I saved some of the cheese for the top.  I used 5 jumbo eggs but 6 would have been better with the extra stuff I added.  Next time I will add some crushed red pepper or use some pepper jack cheese for some kick.  The family LOVED it.  This is a recipe you can do anything with.  Bacon would have been fabulous in it.  It is a keeper.

Made this for the first time this morning and it turned out great.  Very easy to prepare......I used a bag of fresh spinach..white onion....some grape tomatoes.....garlic......salt and pepper....and cheddar cheese......mixed it all with the eggs and baked it in a square baking dish. My husband loved it.....the leftovers will be gone by the end of the day...

Oh, my gosh!!  This is absolutely fabulous!  I admit that I did change things just a little, though. I used Pam cooking spray instead of oil and added 1/2 tsp. of minced garlic and a can of mushrooms (diced) to the veggies. I didn't have muenster, so I substituted 2 cups of sharp cheddar. Since I was using more veggies than the original recipe called for, I also added an extra egg (I used medium eggs). I also baked this in a frozen pie shell, so mine was not crustless. I think I just found a new favorite meal!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very easy and tastey recipe.  Although very similar to the quiche cups in the original South Beach book, we found it very good to eat.  We have played around with the recipe and found that mushrooms, asparagus, brocoli, tomatoes, ground turkey, turkey bacon and different cheese work well also.  Fontina and Havarti were tasty.  Also, we did add a few drops of hot sauce.  I recommend Franks and not Tabasco as Tabasco is not recommended for cooking.  It adds way to much heat as it is a hotter condiment and intended to be added after food is cooked.  

This is my second go round on the South Beach diet and it tends to be a little repetative during phase one so this was a good change!

Great, easy recipe. I used 8 eggs and half a bag of fresh spinach. I only had sliced Muenster cheese so I tore the slices into small pieces and mixed it in with the egg mixture and placed 4 slices on top of the quiche. I would reduce the sodium or omit it all together since the quiche was a bit too salty for me.

I used green peppers for half the onion & a third cup of milk, garlic powder, swiss & cheddar cheese I had which I floured w/ 2 tbsp. flour.  Was very tastey but a bit heavy/dense for quiche.  Replacing a cup of cheese and an egg w/ 8 oz. sour cream or plain yogurt, baking at 375 for 45min- an hr. would give it a lighter, creamier texture.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I usually make new recipes as is the 1st time through, however, as I had extra veggies in the fridge to use up, I changed things up a bit. I used 4 green onions, one bell pepper, two roma tomatoes - all chopped and sautéed in a bit of OO and maybe a tsp of minced garlic until soft. Added in the spinach and cooked off the liquid. Added this veggie mix to a bowl of: 7 whisked eggs, 2 cups shredded mozzarella cheese, the S&P as stated, about a 1/2 Tbsp dried marjoram (basil would do just fine as well). And baked for 30 min at 350 - eggs set and a bit golden brown. Turned out delicious! Will be making again!

Great, and pretty quick to throw together. I substituted feta cheese, taste preference and also it cuts a total of 300 calories for the whole dish. I also cut mine into 8 servings instead of 6, so total calories per piece was only 194. The spinach and feta combo tasted like I was eating spanokopita (Greek spinach cheese pie) and it was so delicious! I could see this being a great appetizer for that reason, baking in a muffin pan.

I had every intention of making this is in a glass pie dish as the recipe suggests. When I got ready to assemble, I realized I couldn’t find the pie dish. text:
I adjusted the recipe only because I didn’t have the exact ingredients called for.  It still turned out absolutely delicious! I used:  cheddar cheese; 1/2 of medium onion; fresh spinach and approximately 1 cup of chopped deli honey ham.  The great thing about the recipe is that you can manipulate the ingredients to suit your taste.  It was done in exactly 30 minutes. I let it set for 5 minutes and served.  I feel it serves four nicely.  If you have 6 people, I would make two.  It is great reheated in microwave.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe several times with the following changes: I used 20 ounces of fresh spinach, steamed first.  I then added it to the onions while cooking to give it some flavor. I also added 2 teaspoons of minced garlic to the onions. While that was cooking, I shredded the cheese. I couldn't get muenster cheese as a block so I used half sharp cheddar and half Monterey Jack. To the cheese and egg (I only used 4, not 5) I added thyme and basil, a teaspoon each. I have also added other vegetables to this, like zucchini or peas, and mushrooms. If you like bacon, this would be good also. This made a very, very yummy dish.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
SO many reviews!  I read as many as I could and took a few into account when making this.  I did increase the eggs to 8,  used a splash of half and half, used whatever cheeses I had in the fridge (swiss, cheddar, mozzarella - it's a GREAT way to use up cheese before it goes green!), 10 oz bag of frozen chopped spinach which I sauted in a non-stick pan - then added a couple pats of butter and dumped in chopped onion and cooked on low until moisture was all but gone.  mixed everything together and dumped in a pie plate. I quartered some grape tomatoes and placed them on top and sprinkled on some grated Parmesan.    Baked for exactly 30 minutes and it is AWESOME!!  Thanks so much for your recipe and for other's reviews about what they did.
