text:
Made a few subs as did others. Combined Guiness Stout cheddar, sharp white cheddar and parmesan cheese.  Gave the dish a deep rich earthy flavor.  Also placed diced tomatoes on top with more shredded parmesan to add color and even browning.  Finally, because let the mixture sit in fridge overnight, added additional egg and a bit ( 1/8-1/4) c of heavy cream.   Assembled in morning and it was wonderful.  Told my husband I could add this or that and he said, leave it just like you did it.

I've made this several times, trying out different cheeses each time, and adding 1/2 cup to one cup of whole milk or half & half to lighten the dense filling a bit. I think it could benefit from some cooked onion or green onion, some chopped ham, a 1/4 tsp. of nutmeg or something to elevate the flavor a bit.

text:
I cute the recipe down to make for two people, used 3 eggs, one 6 oz bag of fresh spinach, 6 T of red pepper, 5 whole mushrooms, 3T chopped onion which I sauteed in olive oil.  I squeezed all of the liquid out of the spinach mixture and added to the 3 eggs and one cup of cheese with 1/4 t salt.  Baked for 30 min and it was excellent. Next time I may add  one more pinch of salt and possibly some garlic.  You could throw any veggie in this and it would be good, you do not miss the crust at all.

userID:
21079989
Display Name:
Darla, Pittsburgh PA
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading all the reviews, I agree -- this is a great base recipe.  I made the following changes.  I used a normal sized bag of fresh baby spinach that I cooked in olive oil.  When the spinach was about 1/2 way done I added minced garlic, minced onion, diced red pepper and fresh mushrooms that I sliced.  Meanwhile I beat 10 eggs, added a some milk and used a whole bag of Kraft Italian blend cheese.  Once the veggies cooled I added them to the egg mixture.  Buttered a deep dish casserole pan, poured the mix in.  Sliced grape tomatoes in 1/2 and placed on top.  Then I grated fresh Asiago cheese on top of the tomatoes, sprinkled with some fresh ground pepper and into the oven it went.  350 for about 22 minutes.  It was PERFECT!  Will make again!!

None
text:
I followed the recipe as stated. The onion I used was yellow and large; I was surprised that it gave a sweetness to the quiche when first baked. Otherwise, the quiche has a very mild flavor, bland. The recipe is simple and would be helped by adding some savory items.  I noticed that the sweetness was not noticeable when I reheated the quiche the next day.   The next time I make this I will add chopped bacon or ham and maybe some hot sauce. The recipe filled a 9” pie pan plus a one cup ramekin.

We loved it and the  recipe was easy to make it be your own. I added some mushrooms, 2 slices of crumbled crisp bacon, used 3 cheeses: munester, cottage cheese and feta and added some nutmeg. The quiche took 10 minutes longer than suggested before it was done and that may due to changes I made.  Definitely a keeper.

text:
I took elements from this and another recipe and changed it a bit. Instead of the 5 eggs and 3 c. Muenster cheese, I used 3 eggs, 1 cup low fat cottage cheese, 1/2 cup low fat grated cheddar,  and 1/4 cup grated parmesan. I also added sliced mushrooms to the spinach saute mixture.  I make this often, and usually double the recipe. You'll need to double the cooking time if you double the recipe. And,  adding cooked turkey sausage is a nice change.

text:
I would love to say I made this as written, but I can't lie, I didn't.
I used fresh spinach, Mexican cheese blend and keeping with the Latin theme, a couple of teaspoons of Taco seasoning. I also added a cup of non-fat milk because, in my world, quiche needs milk. What came out of my oven was a golden-brown, puffy, pan of deliciousness. If I had any less self control I would have eaten the whole thing.  Play with it, and find out what other wonderful things you can do with this recipe.

Nice recipe, but not really a "crustless quiche".  Quiche is made with cream or milk as well as a crust.  This is a frittata.  I use whatever cheese I have on hand and enjoy the addition of mushrooms and/or artichokes, too.  Monterrey Jack is a good substitute cheese if you don't have Muenster.

This was a great foundation for a recipe....however, I’ve made a quiche before so I was able to adjust the recipe for something a bit different. I used 6 eggs, 1 and 1/4 bag of shredded Italian mix cheese,  a 5oz bag of fresh spinach, some cubed ham (no real measurement but enough to know the amount was going to work), 1/2 chopped onion, and chopped white mushrooms.  And I had to cook it for 45 minutes at 350 b/c there was more substance tot he dish. Came out beautifully!!!  It was a great brunch quiche!

userID:
7609069
Display Name:
Susan Quinn
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5362434.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this dish! I eat it every morning for breakfast. It's a delicious way to get vegetables into your breakfast and start the day off right. I have made this as written, but I have added these changes that work out very well based on other reviewers comments:
1. I don't add any salt to this dish - the cheese adds enough sodium to be salty enough.
2. I add whatever leftover veggies I have on hand. Sometimes broccoli, but usually I will add sweet bell peppers or jalapenos. I add about 1 cup of extra veggies and fry them up with the onions and spinach.
3. I increase the eggs to 10 medium sized eggs. 
4. I use whatever cheese I have on hand, and not very much of it. Probably about 2 cups. Usually I add feta, but I love adding pepper jack if I have it.
5. Lastly, I bake these in greased muffin tins (it makes 24) for about 20 minutes. They store beautifully in the freezer and I pop 2 in the microwave for 30 seconds each morning for breakfast. 
Thank you for this wonderful recipe!

text:
This is a good base recipe, I had friends show up unexpectedly and whipped this up for lunch with what I had on hand. Now for the changes... I carmelized the onions, added 1 T of minced garlic (from a jar), added diced ham (lunch meat ham), I used sharp cheddar on the bottom of the pie pan (it made a crust of sorts), monteray jack for the mix in cheese. I also added 2 T of full fat rocotta and blended into the eggs with a splash of heavy cream. They are it all and requested I make it again so I'll take that as a success.

city:

country:
None
text:
The first time I made this, I mostly followed the recipe, except I substituted Swiss cheese for the Muenster, since my grocery store's selection was limited, and I also added 2 extra eggs.  It was very good.

The second time I made this, I used a 12oz. package of chopped spinach, Swiss cheese, a chopped and sauteed onion, some heavy cream, more eggs, and a whole package of bacon, cooked and crumbled.  Even better!

The third time was the best - 9 eggs, 1/4 C. heavy cream, 12 oz. chopped spinach, lots of sharp white cheddar, one chopped and sauteed onion, and a package of cooked and crumbled sausage, baked for an hour.  Very tasty, filling, and low-carb!

That's what's great about this recipe, you can monkey with it all you like, and the results are still fabulous!

Display Name:
LISAD

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
AWESOME recipe! I hate to be “one of those people” who comments on the original recipe with a bunch of alterations, but I just had to pass on my remarks because this is a truly versatile recipe - and pretty hard to screw up! I swapped the onions for chopped green onions/scallions sautéed in oil and minced garlic. To lighten the recipe a bit, I used 3 whole eggs + the equivalent of 3 eggs (via egg beaters/whites in a carton). I only used 2.5 cups of sharp cheddar (which tasted awesome with the green onions!). By the time I added the onions/spinach mixture to the egg/cheese mixture it was pretty thick. So I dumped a little bit of milk in there to thin it out. Not much - but just enough. Threw in a dash of nutmeg and baked it in a glass pie dish for approx 30 mins and let it set up for 10+ mins. This is a fantastic recipe!! So easy and versatile! I can’t imagine it with crust - I feel like a crust would take away from how flavorful it is without!

text:
This is not really quiche. More like egg pie. There's no milk or cream to make a custardy body with the eggs. And the spices are rather boring.  So if you want a creamier, richer, more flavorful dish add two cups of milk or half and half and nutmeg. much better with just those two additions. It is a good breakfast casserole as written however, though rather flavorless.

text:
Very tasty!  I like to follow a recipe exactly the first time. Amazingly I had everything I needed. Cooked in an 8x8 glass dish. 30 minutes. Didn’t turn out super fluffy but not too thin either. Yes it was very dense with spinach but I liked that. Also if you reduce the spinach the saltiness might be overpowering. Next time I might try a combination of cheeses and less or no salt. Kids don’t like mushrooms or that would have been a perfect combination.  Good starting point to adding bacon, skipping the salt, adding a crust.

text:
First try for quiche and it was wonderful. This recipe is a keeper. I had fresh spinach so I wilted it and place on cutting board to cut into pieces as other reviewer suggested. I had gouda, mozzarella, Irish sharp cheese in the frig and I added a German soft cheese with a pecorino shredded all left over from another recipe and it made the dish. What I really like is that the leftovers (there's only two of us) were great for two lunches. Yum. Will definitely make this again. Don't miss the crust or the calories. :-)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good base for a very adaptable quiche. I cooked up some mushrooms with the onions and added some bacon I'd already fried the morning before. I had a strange collection of cheeses on hand so I put 1 cup fresh parmesan and 1 cup of cottage cheese in the quiche, then sprinkled a little leftover aged cheddar on top. Came out better than I expected, so I'm pretty sure any cheese combination would do - and I think that 2 cup+a bit is plenty rather than the 3 cups called for. I'll probably keep making this which whatever mix-and-match additions or cheese I happen to have around.

SRVCookie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is REALLY good!  Watching our carbs closely, and my SIL is gluten free, so this was a great find.  I've made it several times.  It is very good as written, and this reheats nicely in the microwave (reheat a slice 1 - 2 min only).  Over time, I've played with this depending on what I've had on hand, and the recipe adapts readily to changes in cheeses or herbs.  I've used part cottage cheese before, and I sometimes add 6 oz. of plain yogurt to the mix.  We usually have cheddar and jack in the house so our standard is to mix these two for the cheese component.  Gruyere and cheddar is really good too.  I've added a pinch of cayenne or a couple of Tablespoons of salsa before.  Fresh parsley or thyme.  It all works.    I STRONGLY recommend cooks add 1/2 - 3/4 tsp ground mustard powder to the eggs.  For new cooks, ground mustard adds a special something that really perks up the flavor to  dishes with eggs and cheese.  You'll see the mustard powder in a lot of recipes for macaroni and cheese or frittatas etc..  No, your dish won't have any mustard taste.  Thanks for this recipe!
Review:

5

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great, easy recipe for quiche. I sauteed all the veggies first: sliced green onions, thinly sliced ham, mushrooms, and fresh spinach. Then, I whipped up 7 eggs and 1/4 cup of milk  and 2 cups of shredded cheese and parmesan until foamy. I didn't have a round pie pan, so I poured the mixture into a 8X8 brownie pan, adding in the veggies and then another layer of egg over the mixture. It took 50 minutes to cook, browned around the edges and top—it was delicious! I served it with a tossed salad with ranch dressing. Next time, I will try adding crumbled pork sausage to the egg mixture.

text:
Great recipe especially for low-carb diets.  I followed others' suggestions and added a little chopped fresh garlic, chopped Canadian bacon (or ham) and reduced the cheese to 2 cups.  I also added 2 tbsp plain Greek yogurt to the egg mixture for flavour and texture.  

Makes 12 individual quiches in a regular size muffin pan and bakes in 20 minutes.

Tasty and filling for breakfast.  I will definitely make again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not a huge fan of Quiche due to the texture of it being so soft.  I chose this dish because it looked simple enough to prepare and I had the ingredients, except for the cheese, already on hand.  I have attempted quiche before but have never been this successful.
It turned out to be easy enough.  I used my castiron skillet instead of a baking dish, and used more Spinach than was called for.  The texture turned out much firmer than I expected, which is one of the things I like best about it.   The flavor is still mild.  This seems to be a nice basic dish that could be modified easily, as many of the other reviewers have done.

text:
This was a delicious success all around! I will admit to finding the process of drying out the frozen spinach quite tedious, but I do believe it to be the most effective way doing so. I misread the recipe and bought shredded mozzarella cheese instead of muenster and I used 4 jumbo eggs because that's what I had on hand and did not want to make the result too eggy. I skipped the salt and pepper entirely and also used an 8x8 baking pan instead of a pie tin. The resulting quiche was very solid but tasted wonderful - seconds all around! This recipe is definitely a keeper - Thanks for sharing!

text:
Good just as the recipe is written, but changes and additions are easy to make. I prefer fresh baby spinach to frozen. Just add to the cooked onions long enough to wilt the spinach. It is easy to add additional vegetables such as grated carrots. Use whatever kind of cheese you like. I  may add cooked bacon and a friend added sausage. Sometimes I top with thinly sliced tomato and sprinkle with additional cheese.

Display Name:
horsepro

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7682907.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve been making this for years but with a twist. I add 1 small container of fat free ricotta to the mix. I also add one teaspoon Siracha to the eggs when beating them. Then lightly grease a pan, peel and slice a sweet potato into thin potato chip size slices and lay them in the baking pan, pie pan or quiche pan, I place the slices all-round the edges and cover the bottom. You can substitute any kind of potato for this part. If I use a russet, I wash well and leave the peeling on, It makes for a nice and tasty presentation and it also serves to soak up some of the liquid that you normally get with quiche, especially if you put moist cheeses in it.
Personally, I never cared for a pastry crust with quiche, but I understand the real purpose of it is to absorb all that moisture from the cheese’s.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-05-21T14:14:00.88

text:
Read other reviews and made slight alterations:

Used 10 oz package of spinach, 
sautéed in carmelized garlic and olive oil
6 eggs
1/3 cup half and half
1 cup onion
1 bunch of green onions
1 cup swiss, 1 cup cheddar, 1/4 cup parmesan reggiano
salt and pepper
Garnished with a half dozen grape tomatoes out of the garden.

I will be eating this quiche base for the rest of my life.

text:
The only change I made to this was to use mozzarella cheese (because it was on hand), and it still came out delicious, enough that my vegetable-hating husband helped himself to another serving. Super easy to prepare, which is a plus on weeknights after a long day at work. The amount of spinach is just right. If you prepare everything as directed and bake per instructions, this does NOT come out "thin and stiff" as another reviewer commented. Would definitely make this again, as is.

Excellent but I changed it up a bit for our taste. Her is what I Did: 1/4 purple onion and 2 green peppers chopped and sautéed . 6 large eggs. 150g spinach frozen and sautéed . 1.5 cups low fat cheddar. 1/2 cup cottage cheese 1/2 cup feta . 1/4 cup milk .1/4 cup bacon bits or ham . 1/4 teaspoon garlic salt and salt and pepper to taste . Cook 35 minutes in 8 inch pan

I only had four eggs in my fridge, and about 2/3 of an 8oz bag of fresh spinach and I sent my husband to the store to get me a bag of shredded cheddar, but he wouldn't get me an onion, so I made do. I baked it for only 25 min as my oven tends to burn things if I follow cooking times, and it came out browned so I'm sure 5 more min would've ruined it. It came out a bit thin, but that's probably because of the lack of 5th egg, but other than that the taste was great and the texture and consistency was good too. I would definitely make this again. text:
This is a great, low-carb recipe that can be easily tweaked for your own tastes.  I typically use cheddar cheese, because we like that the best, but you can easily use different cheeses or combinations of cheeses.  I've also made this recipe with chard, and I would think that kale or other sautéed and drained greens would work well too.  I see other reviewers add in mushrooms, sun-dried tomatoes, artichokes, etc.  You can sprinkle in your favorite herbs, as well.  Lots of variations available.  Thank you for sharing this recipe.

text:
squeezing the spinach aside, this is a pretty easy recipe with tasty results, even if you don't follow the recipe faithfully. my last onion went bad, so i used dried granulated onion. i also reduced the cheese to 1 cup of whatever I had available (equal parts cheddar and parmesan cheeses) and used ~6-7 packed cups fresh spinach. One cup cheese was plenty cheesy for me, so 3 seems excessive. even with the substitutions and omissions, i thought it came out delicious. definitely will make again.

text:
I've made this recipe several times, it is five star as is, but over time I've made a few adjustments. I start with the oil and onion in a dutch oven. I add a teaspoon of minced garlic. I then add a 10 ounce bag of fresh spinach leaves, and just cook them down, then if I have any fresh mushrooms, I slice and add them to the pot (up to a cup or so). Finally, I add just a couple of shakes (or pinches) of red pepper flakes for a kick (then add it to the egg/cheese mixture). My whole family loves it! Thanks for the recipe!

Display Name:
Catalina Morales

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
It turned out so well that my hubby thought it was store bought!!!..lol. He had such a proud look on his face when I told him that I actually made it. I cut down on the some of the yolks and added an extra egg white to subtitute. I also used fresh spinach. There is no need to cook it in advance, but I think it would be a good idea to do so if you have a lot of it so that it looses volume and it will all fit. Medium cheddar cheese was on sale so that was the way to go this time. Oh, and I only used 1 cup so that the flavor doesn't overpower everything else and to cut down the calories/fat. For the pan, I used a rectangular loaf pan so that the quiche would come out thicker. This way it's good for 3-4 generous servings. You can also add a few squirts of hot sauce or chipotle sauce to spice it up! I served with bbq vine ripened tomatos (seasoned with garlic, salt & pepper) and a thick slice of traditional style ham thrown on the bbq as well to warm up and get some grill marks. Thanks for sharing!

This was a delicious and healthy meal! I added an additional egg, garlic salt, a little nutmeg, a little cayenne pepper and a splash of milk. I only used half of an onion. text:
I like having a quiche with no crust, which can sometimes make it so heavy. I sauteed the onion with a small can of drained and chopped mushrooms. I only used three eggs, and it worked well (less eggy and more spinach). For the cheese, I used about a cup each of sharp cheddar and cottage cheese, a little mozzarella and grated parmesan (which I also sprinkled on top). Also added a little nutmeg, cayenene, garlic and onion powders, and fresh basil. Baked closer to 40 min and let rest for 10 min. Thanks for the easy and delicious recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great base recipe.  I combined some tips from other reviews.  Added splash of skim milk. Used only half a bag of spinach and 2 c of cheese (1 c each of cheddar and mozzarella) and 1/4 Vidalia onion.  Added 1/3c chopped ham and dash of nutmeg, as well as 2 crushed garlic cloves.  Topped with halved grape tomatoes and sprinkled with shredded parm.  Great except that was too much garlic (my fault) even though we are crazy about garlic.  I make this frequently now and sort of double the recipe and cook in a 9x13 glass baking dish for 40-45 minutes. 10 eggs, about 4 c cheese but just 1 bag frozen spinach.  Cooking or defrosting the spinach so you can drain it really helps keep the quiche from getting too watery.  I also add 1-2 c frozen broccoli (in the double recipe) and cook with the spinach.  A cup of crumbled or cubed feta in the cheese mix really perks up the flavor.

text:
I made this tonight and was pleasantly surprised!  I'm on day 7 of the Dr. Atkins diet (5 lbs down, woohoo!) and this was just the meal I needed to keep going.  Flavorful, filling and most of all, low carb!
I lined my 8x8 pan (I don't have a pie dish yet) with butter - after all, it's low carb!  I used 2 cups up cheddar instead of Muenster cheese and only half of a large white onion.  I also crumbled 5 strips of bacon and mixed it in.  It was fantastic!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I had a can of spinach I needed to use, which worked very well in place of the frozen spinach.  After browning the onion, I drained the can of spinach and cooked it with the onion until the water had steamed off.  I took the advice of another reviewer here and added a pinch of nutmeg, a little garlic pepper and some chopped scallions.  I had some fresh guacamole in the refrigerator and spread it on top of my slice of quiche.  The flavors of the quiche and the guacamole went incredibly well together!

I made this today and my friends loved it.  Here are the alterations I made:  I used 2 cups of mild chedder/monteray jack cheese (Sargento brand), 1 cup of sharp chedder cheese, and a handful of parmesean cheese (probably 2-6 tablespoons).  I also liberally buttered the pie pan with unsalted butter.  Everything else was the same.

text:
This recipe was so tasty and very! After reading some of the reviews, I altered the recipe a bit.  Instead of adding 3 cups of Muenster cheese, I added about 3/4 cup low fat cottage cheese, 3/4 cup reduced fat sharp cheddar, and 3/4 cup reduced fat monterrey jack cheese.  Instead of regular salt I added a little bit of Lowry's seasoning. I also added some cut up turkey sausage links for some substance. This was such a great recipe.  Thank you!

I have made this 2x already and both times turned out great.  First time I added some spinach and broccoli.  I sauted some frozen peppers and some fresh potato shreds.  I would recommend if you use broccoli to start out with small amounts.  I used fresh broccoli from my garden and to me that is all you could taste even though I had many other flavors in there.  I cut back on the cheese just to make it a bit more healthy and used more egg whites than full eggs.  You can tweak this to your hearts delight.

text:
I have made this for 2 brunch parties, and both times it was a hit. If you like spinach and eggs - this will not disappoint.  I found that Muenster cheese is a bit pricy, and you have to shred it yourself (something I am not a fan of).  Shredding 2 cups took awhile, but it was worth it in the end!  Also, I only used 1/2 cup finely chopped onion... which was less than 1/2 yellow onion.  I suppose the amount you use is a personal preference, or maybe I just had a huge onion!

text:
I was looking for a crustless quiche recipe, and I'm glad I came across this one. I actually changed the ingredients of this recipe quite a bit to suit what I had on hand, but it turned out great, and I am sure it would be great as written. I used 2 cups shredded mozzarella and 1 cup shredded sharp cheddar (instead of muenster), and 1 cup raw shredded carrots (instead of spinach), and I added 3 cloves minced garlic to the onions while they cooked. It was delicious and enjoyed by everyone in the family, even the 4year old :). Thanks!

text:
This is a fabulous low carb recipe. You don't feel cheated at all eating this. I didn't have Muenster cheese so I just used 2 cups shredded cheddar & 1 cup mozzarella. I keep a couple of cans of spinach in the cupboard to save on freezer space & it works almost as well as frozen. You just have to make sure it's rinsed & drained. The onions really add flavor. Either way it is YUM-MEE!!!

text:
For some reason, I don't have a pie pan, so at the suggestion of another user, I made these in muffin tins.  It filled 12 muffin tins perfectly.  This is a terrific recipe and sets up very nicely, although I definitely think it's too spinach-y and I love spinach, so it's not that.  I had to use Monterey Jack cheese instead of Muenster (which is obviously more mild) because I couldn't find shredded muenster anywhere and shredding it myself seemed difficult since it's so soft.  In retrospect, I should have used the muenster, but I would have used 2 cups rather than three.  Next time I'm adding bacon and decreasing the spinach content just a bit.

text:
This is of course really tasty, but it's also very high in fat. Quiche is usually high in fat (since it's mostly eggs and cheese), but I was looking for one with lots of veggies and no crust to lower the fat/calorie content. This one isn't that great as such, but does taste very good. I recommend replacing some of the cheese with sour cream or lower fat cream cheese to lighten it up a bit.

This turned out to be a very good recipe. I made a few changes to accomodate my personal tastes but the recipe is good as is. I added mushrooms to the spinach and onions. I used a combination of mozzarella, colby jack, and cottage cheese. To the eggs I added a few drops of Frank's hot sauce and 2 teaspoons of prepared mustard. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good base recipe.  I cut it down to 2-3 servings.  I sauteed 1/4 cup chopped onion and a small can of mushrooms in olive oil, then added about 1/4 pound of fresh baby spinach until wilted. Mixed with 2 beaten eggs, 3/4 cup shredded cheddar cheese, S & P, and some dried basil and oregano and baked for 20 minutes.  It made a nice breakfast with sausage links and fresh fruit.  Next time I'll add some cooked bulk pork sausage to the mix before baking to make a one-dish breakfast!

text:
Very good recipe.  It definitely needs to be spiced up.  I added carmelized half red onion, chili powder, curry powder, and salt.  I also added chopped bell peppers.  I reduced the number of eggs to three and used two cups of sharp cheddar cheese (instead of the recommended three cups).  I took the liberty of adding some sour cream which gave it a really nice flavor.  Had to keep it in the oven slightly longer (at least 35 minutes).  Overall, good for breakfast or brunch!

text:
This was really good! I tripled the recipe- 2 for work, 1 for the fam and they loved it.  I used 8 cups of Mexican shredded cheese and about 1.5 cups of finely shredded 75% fat free sharp white cheddar.  I drained the spinach using a colander and the back of a spoon to get most of the juice out.  I also cooked the spinach with the onions.  I was a little scared that I didn't dry the spinach enough and also the batter was really thick compared to other quiche batters I have made but it turned out great! My coworkers and family really enjoyed this recipe!

text:
This was a pretty excellent recipe, although I didn't follow it exactly.  I used pieces of swiss cheese and low fat feta instead of muenster (I love the flavor of feta), and I used fresh spinach instead of frozen.  I just threw the spinach in the skillet for a few seconds after sauteing the other ingredients, just enough to wilt it a little bit.  I also added two cloves of garlic to the onion in the skillet.  The cooking time was right on target!  My husband loved it - we ate the whole thing between the two of us!

text:
I just made this with a few minor differences, and my roommate and I have decided it's the best quiche we've ever had.  I accidentally didn't buy enough muenster, so I used a cup of shredded 2% mild cheddar.  I think that made it so much richer.  Next time I think I'll use a cup of extra sharp cheddar and see how that tastes.  

Last summer I was on the South Beach diet for a week.  I hated it, but some of the recipes weren't too bad.  They have a crustless quiche that isn't nearly as good, but I stole their idea of using aluminum muffin cups to bake in.  They came out beautifully and perfectly portioned.  Yum.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

So easy and love the "no crust"!  I used fresh spinach and cut back the cheese, Monteray Jack and Motzarella to one cup each. It was a little salty for me(don't use it) so I might get low salt cheese next time, otherwise, super!  I will make for my company next week with another recipe from here, Banana Fruit Smoothie.

I basically cut this recipe down so it only used two eggs so I could make my own personal quiche and it turned out great! It didn't take long at all and I found it to be delicious! Normally I have trouble with quiches because the eggs don't set, but this one was no problem! I added a tablespoon or so of milk to the eggs because I find it makes them a little fluffier, but other than that I didn't change a thing. Will definitely make again and again and maybe try throwing in some more veggies or something in the future.

text:
Just made this recipe, EXTREMELY tasty! I made my own little version though, I didn't have enough eggs - so I only used two. I didn't mind that it was more vegetable based than egg based, but it still tasted fine. I added bacon which I think enhanced the whole dish. For cheese, I used what I had and added mozzerella and feta. I think the feta with the spinach and the bacon meld very well together, and gave it a little kick. I also added tomatos to the dish, since its one of my favorites. Awesome dish, will be making it again.

I really liked this recipe!  I made a few changes, added some ham cubes and milk rather than some of the cheese.  I was a little concerned that the bottom would burn without the crust but it turned out great!

text:
I love quiche, but this just didn't do it for me.  I made it twice.  The first time just as the recipe says and I found it too cheesy and not eggy enough.  The second time I made it with less cheese, added 2 more eggs, some mushrooms, and used pepper jack instead of meunster because another reviewer suggested it.  Somehow it was still too bland.
